name: CS7637 KBAI Exam 1

Multi-Correct MC

fields: Conundrum: Intelligent agents have {{c1::limited resources}}.
Lesson 01 - Fundamental Conundrums of AI
Conundrum: Computation is {{c1::local}}, but problems have {{c2::global constraints}}.
Lesson 01 - Fundamental Conundrums of AI
Conundrum: Logic is {{c1::deductive}}, but many problems are {{c2::not}}.
Lesson 01 - Fundamental Conundrums of AI (exact slide wording)
Conundrum: The world is {{c1::dynamic}}, but knowledge is {{c2::limited}}.
Lesson 01 - Fundamental Conundrums of AI
Conundrum: Problem solving, reasoning, and learning are complex, but {{c1::explanation and justification}} are even more complex.
Lesson 01 - Fundamental Conundrums of AI (5th conundrum)
AI Problems: Knowledge often arrives {{c1::incrementally}}.
Lesson 01 - Characteristics of AI Problems
AI Problems: Problems exhibit {{c1::recurring patterns}}.
Lesson 01 - Characteristics of AI Problems
AI Problems: Problems have {{c1::multiple levels of granularity}}.
Lesson 01 - Characteristics of AI Problems
AI Problems: Many problems are {{c1::computationally intractable}}.
Lesson 01 - Characteristics of AI Problems
AI Problems: The world is {{c1::dynamic}}, but knowledge of the world is {{c2::static}}.
Lesson 01 - Characteristics of AI Problems
AI Problems: The world is {{c1::open-ended}}, but knowledge is {{c2::limited}}.
Lesson 01 - Characteristics of AI Problems
AI Agents: Agents have limited {{c1::computing power}}.
Lesson 01 - Characteristics of AI Agents
AI Agents: Agents have limited {{c1::sensors}}.
Lesson 01 - Characteristics of AI Agents
AI Agents: Agents have limited {{c1::attention}}.
Lesson 01 - Characteristics of AI Agents
AI Agents: Computational logic is fundamentally {{c1::deductive}}.
Lesson 01 - Characteristics of AI Agents
AI Agents: AI agents' knowledge is {{c1::incomplete}} relative to the world.
Lesson 01 - Characteristics of AI Agents
The four schools of AI are defined by two axes: {{c1::thinking vs. acting}} and {{c2::optimally vs. like humans}}.
Lesson 01 - Four Schools of AI
Think optimally examples: {{c1::semantic web}}, {{c2::machine learning}}.
Lesson 01 - Four Schools of AI
Act optimally example: {{c1::airplane autopilot}}.
Lesson 01 - Four Schools of AI
Act like humans example: {{c1::improvisational robots}}.
Lesson 01 - Four Schools of AI
Cognitive Systems: Systems that exhibit {{c1::human-like intelligence}} through processes like learning, reasoning, and memory.
Lesson 01 - Cognitive Systems
Three layers of cognitive architecture: {{c1::Metacognition}}, {{c2::Deliberation}}, {{c3::Reaction}}.
Lesson 01 - Cognitive Systems
Deliberation contains: {{c1::Reasoning}}, {{c2::Learning}}, {{c3::Memory}}.
Lesson 01 - Cognitive Systems
Raven's Progressive Matrices: Test written in the {{c1::1930s}} to examine {{c2::general intelligence}}.
Lesson 02 - Raven's Progressive Matrices
Raven's matrices are unique in that problems are strictly {{c1::visual}}.
Lesson 02 - Raven's Progressive Matrices
Three types of Raven's problems: {{c1::2x1}}, {{c2::2x2}}, {{c3::3x3}}.
Lesson 02 - Raven's Progressive Matrices
Principle 1: KBAI agents represent {{c1::and organize}} knowledge into knowledge structures to guide {{c2::and support}} reasoning.
Lesson 02 - 7 Principles (CORRECTED - exact slide wording)
Principle 2: Learning in KBAI agents is often {{c1::incremental}}.
Lesson 02 - 7 Principles
Principle 3: Reasoning in KBAI agents is {{c1::top-down}} as well as {{c2::bottom-up}}.
Lesson 02 - 7 Principles
Principle 4: KBAI agents {{c1::match methods to tasks}}.
Lesson 02 - 7 Principles
Principle 5: KBAI agents use {{c1::heuristics}} to find solutions that are {{c2::good enough}}, though not necessarily optimal.
Lesson 02 - 7 Principles
Principle 6: KBAI agents make use of {{c1::recurring patterns}} in the problems they solve.
Lesson 02 - 7 Principles
Principle 7: The architecture of KBAI agents enables {{c1::reasoning}}, {{c2::learning}}, and {{c3::memory}} to support and constrain each other.
Lesson 02 - 7 Principles
Semantic network: {{c1::nodes}} represent concepts, {{c2::directional links}} represent relationships.
Lesson 03 - Semantic Networks
Semantic network structure: Lexically = {{c1::nodes}}, Structurally = {{c2::directional links}}, Semantically = {{c3::application-specific labels}}.
Lesson 03 - Semantic Networks
Good representations make {{c1::relationships explicit}}.
Lesson 03 - Good Representations
Good representations expose {{c1::natural constraints}}.
Lesson 03 - Good Representations
Good representations bring {{c1::objects and relations}} together.
Lesson 03 - Good Representations
Good representations exclude {{c1::extraneous details}}.
Lesson 03 - Good Representations
Good representations are: transparent, concise, complete, {{c1::fast}}, {{c2::computable}}.
Lesson 03 - Good Representations
Guards & Prisoners: boat may take only {{c1::one or two}} people at a time.
Lesson 03 - Guards & Prisoners
Guards & Prisoners: prisoners may never {{c1::outnumber guards}} on either coast.
Lesson 03 - Guards & Prisoners
The 3-3 Guards & Prisoners problem takes {{c1::11}} moves to solve.
Lesson 03 - Guards & Prisoners
Generate and Test: {{c1::generate}} possible solutions, then {{c2::test}} if they are valid.
Lesson 04 - Generate and Test
Good generator property: {{c1::complete}} - generates all possible solutions.
Lesson 04 - Generate and Test
Good generator property: {{c1::efficient}} - doesn't waste resources.
Lesson 04 - Generate and Test
Good generator property: {{c1::smart}} - generates likely solutions first.
Lesson 04 - Generate and Test
Means-ends analysis: for each operator, calculate {{c1::difference}} between new state and {{c2::goal state}}.
Lesson 05 - Means-Ends Analysis
Means-ends analysis: prefer state that {{c1::minimizes distance}} to goal.
Lesson 05 - Means-Ends Analysis
Means-ends limitation: can fail when solution requires temporarily {{c1::increasing distance}} to goal.
Lesson 05 - Means-Ends Analysis
Problem reduction: break a {{c1::hard problem}} into {{c2::easier subproblems}}.
Lesson 05 - Problem Reduction
Cognitive architecture maps {{c1::percepts}} to {{c2::actions}}.
Lesson 06 - Cognitive Architectures
Cognitive architecture formula: {{c1::Architecture}} + {{c2::Content}} = {{c3::Behavior}}.
Lesson 06 - Cognitive Architectures
Cognitive architecture function: f: {{c1::P*}} → {{c2::A}} (Percepts to Action).
Lesson 06 - Cognitive Architectures
Three levels: {{c1::Task/Knowledge Level}}, {{c2::Algorithm/Symbol Level}}, {{c3::Hardware/Implementation Level}}.
Lesson 06 - Three Levels of Analysis
Task/Knowledge Level examples: {{c1::selecting a pitch}}, {{c2::playing baseball}}.
Lesson 06 - Three Levels
Algorithm/Symbol Level examples: {{c1::means-ends analysis}}, {{c2::semantic networks}}.
Lesson 06 - Three Levels
Hardware/Implementation Level examples: {{c1::a brain}}, {{c2::a transistor}}.
Lesson 06 - Three Levels
SOAR long-term memories: {{c1::Procedural}}, {{c2::Semantic}}, {{c3::Episodic}}.
Lesson 06 - SOAR Architecture
Procedural memory stores {{c1::how to do things}} (production rules).
Lesson 06 - SOAR Memory Types
Semantic memory stores {{c1::facts about the world}}.
Lesson 06 - SOAR Memory Types
Episodic memory stores {{c1::specific experiences}}.
Lesson 06 - SOAR Memory Types
Production rule format: IF {{c1::conditions}} THEN {{c2::actions}}.
Lesson 06 - Production Rules
Chunking: creates a new {{c1::production rule}} from experience to resolve impasses faster.
Lesson 06 - Learning in SOAR
Frame: represents a {{c1::stereotyped situation}} with slots for expected information.
Lesson 07 - Frames
Frame property 1: Frames represent {{c1::stereotypes}}.
Lesson 07 - Properties of Frames
Frame property 2: Frames provide {{c1::default values}}.
Lesson 07 - Properties of Frames
Frame property 3: Frames exhibit {{c1::inheritance}}.
Lesson 07 - Properties of Frames
Learning by recording cases: store {{c1::problem-solution pairs}}, retrieve most {{c2::similar}} case.
Lesson 08 - Learning by Recording Cases
Nearest neighbor: find most similar case by calculating {{c1::distance}} in feature space.
Lesson 08 - Nearest Neighbor
k-Nearest Neighbor: consider {{c1::k closest}} cases, use {{c2::majority voting}} or averaging.
Lesson 08 - k-NN
Case-based assumption: {{c1::Patterns exist}} in the world.
Lesson 08 - Assumptions
Case-based assumption: {{c1::Similar problems}} have {{c2::similar solutions}}.
Lesson 08 - Assumptions
CBR Stage 1 - {{c1::Retrieval}}: retrieving a case from memory similar to current problem.
Lesson 09 - CBR (exact slide wording)
CBR Stage 2 - {{c1::Adaptation}}: adapting the solution to that case to fit current problem.
Lesson 09 - CBR (exact slide wording)
CBR Stage 3 - {{c1::Evaluation}}: evaluating how well adapted solution addresses current problem.
Lesson 09 - CBR (exact slide wording)
CBR Stage 4 - {{c1::Storage}}: storing the new problem and solution as a case.
Lesson 09 - CBR (exact slide wording)
Discrimination tree: organizes cases by asking {{c1::questions about features}}.
Lesson 09 - Case Storage
Incremental concept learning: learns concepts {{c1::one example at a time}}.
Lesson 10 - ICL
Positive example doesn't fit current concept → {{c1::generalize}}.
Lesson 10 - ICL Logic
Negative example fits current concept → {{c1::specialize}}.
Lesson 10 - ICL Logic
{{c1::require-link}}: link must be present to be a positive example of the concept.
Lesson 10 - Specialization Heuristic (exact slide wording)
{{c1::forbid-link}}: link must be absent to be a positive example of the concept.
Lesson 10 - Specialization Heuristic (exact slide wording)
{{c1::drop-link}}: link is not necessary to be a positive example of the concept.
Lesson 10 - Generalization Heuristic (exact slide wording)
{{c1::enlarge-set}}: multiple objects or links may fit one role in the concept.
Lesson 10 - Generalization Heuristic (exact slide wording)
{{c1::climb-tree}}: generalize over multiple objects in the same role based on knowledge.
Lesson 10 - Generalization Heuristic (exact slide wording)
{{c1::close-interval}}: expand range of values to be a positive example of the concept.
Lesson 10 - Generalization Heuristic (exact slide wording)
Classification: maps percepts into {{c1::equivalence classes}}.
Lesson 11 - Classification
{{c1::Axiomatic}} concepts: defined by a formal set of necessary and sufficient conditions.
Lesson 11 - Concept Types (exact slide wording)
Axiomatic example: {{c1::circle}} - all points in a plane equidistant from a single point.
Lesson 11 - Concept Types (exact slide wording)
{{c1::Prototype}} concepts: base concepts defined by a typical example with overridable properties.
Lesson 11 - Concept Types (exact slide wording)
Prototype example: {{c1::chair}}.
Lesson 11 - Concept Types
{{c1::Exemplar}} concepts: defined by implicit abstractions of instances, or exemplars, of the concept.
Lesson 11 - Concept Types (exact slide wording)
Exemplar example: {{c1::beauty}}.
Lesson 11 - Concept Types
Formality ranking (most to least): {{c1::Axiomatic}} → {{c2::Prototype}} → {{c3::Exemplar}}.
Lesson 11 - Concept Types
{{c1::Soundness}}: only valid conclusions can be proven.
Lesson 12 - Logic
{{c1::Completeness}}: all valid conclusions can be proven.
Lesson 12 - Logic
AND (∧): true only if {{c1::both}} operands are true.
Lesson 12 - Logical Operators
OR (∨): true if {{c1::at least one}} operand is true.
Lesson 12 - Logical Operators
NOT (¬): returns the {{c1::opposite}} truth value.
Lesson 12 - Logical Operators
IMPLIES (⇒): A ⇒ B is false only when A is {{c1::true}} and B is {{c2::false}}.
Lesson 12 - Logical Operators
Implication elimination: A ⇒ B becomes {{c1::¬A ∨ B}}.
Lesson 12 - Implication Elimination
Modus Ponens: p ⇒ q, {{c1::p}} ∴ {{c2::q}}.
Lesson 12 - Rules of Inference
Modus Tollens: p ⇒ q, {{c1::¬q}} ∴ {{c2::¬p}}.
Lesson 12 - Rules of Inference
De Morgan's Law: ¬(A ∧ B) ≡ {{c1::¬A ∨ ¬B}}.
Lesson 12 - De Morgan's Law
De Morgan's Law: ¬(A ∨ B) ≡ {{c1::¬A ∧ ¬B}}.
Lesson 12 - De Morgan's Law
Universal quantifier (∀): for {{c1::all}} x.
Lesson 12 - Quantifiers
Existential quantifier (∃): there exists {{c1::at least one}} x.
Lesson 12 - Quantifiers
Resolution theorem proving: assume {{c1::negation}} of goal, derive {{c2::contradiction}}.
Lesson 12 - Resolution
Conjunctive Normal Form (CNF): {{c1::conjunction (AND)}} of {{c2::disjunctions (ORs)}}.
Lesson 12 - CNF
[EXAM] STRIPS operator: {{c1::Precondition}} (what must be true) and {{c2::Postcondition}} (what becomes true).
From Spring 2015 Midterm - NOT in lecture slides
[EXAM] {{c1::Deduction}}: Rule + Cause → Effect.
From Spring 2015 Final Q4 - NOT in lecture slides
[EXAM] {{c1::Induction}}: Cause + Effect → Rule.
From Spring 2015 Final Q4 - NOT in lecture slides
[EXAM] {{c1::Abduction}}: Rule + Effect → Cause.
From Spring 2015 Final Q4 - NOT in lecture slides
Which of the following are fundamental conundrums in AI?

A. Limited computational resources
B. Local computation with global constraints
C. Fully deductive reasoning in all AI problems
D. Dynamic world with incomplete knowledge
E. Guaranteed explainability of agent decisions

✓ A. Limited computational resources
✓ B. Local computation with global constraints
✗ C. Fully deductive reasoning in all AI problems
✓ D. Dynamic world with incomplete knowledge
✗ E. Guaranteed explainability of agent decisions

Correct: A, B, D
Lesson 01 - Section 03
Which are characteristics of AI problems?

A. Data often arrives incrementally
B. Problems exist at only one abstraction level
C. Problems exhibit recurring patterns
D. Many problems are computationally intractable
E. Knowledge changes faster than the world

✓ A. Data often arrives incrementally
✗ B. Problems exist at only one abstraction level
✓ C. Problems exhibit recurring patterns
✓ D. Many problems are computationally intractable
✗ E. Knowledge changes faster than the world

Correct: A, C, D
Lesson 01 - Section 04
Which are properties of AI agents?

A. Unlimited memory
B. Limited sensors
C. Limited attention
D. Incomplete world knowledge
E. Perfect rationality

✗ A. Unlimited memory
✓ B. Limited sensors
✓ C. Limited attention
✓ D. Incomplete world knowledge
✗ E. Perfect rationality

Correct: B, C, D
Lesson 01 - Section 05
Which are fundamental processes of knowledge-based AI?

A. Reasoning
B. Learning
C. Memory
D. Optimization
E. Data visualization

✓ A. Reasoning
✓ B. Learning
✓ C. Memory
✗ D. Optimization
✗ E. Data visualization

Correct: A, B, C
Lesson 01 - Section 10
Which belong to the four schools of AI?

A. Acting optimally
B. Thinking optimally
C. Acting like humans
D. Thinking like humans
E. Acting randomly

✓ A. Acting optimally
✓ B. Thinking optimally
✓ C. Acting like humans
✓ D. Thinking like humans
✗ E. Acting randomly

Correct: A, B, C, D
Lesson 01 - Section 11
Which are learning strategies used in CS7637?

A. Learning by example
B. Learning by doing
C. Project-based learning
D. Learning by memorization
E. Learning by reflection

✓ A. Learning by example
✓ B. Learning by doing
✓ C. Project-based learning
✗ D. Learning by memorization
✓ E. Learning by reflection

Correct: A, B, C, E
Lesson 02 - Section 05
Which are components of a semantic network?

A. Nodes for objects
B. Links for relationships
C. Labeled links
D. Only numerical attributes
E. Directional connections

✓ A. Nodes for objects
✓ B. Links for relationships
✓ C. Labeled links
✗ D. Only numerical attributes
✓ E. Directional connections

Correct: A, B, C, E
Lesson 03 - Section 08
Which describe a good knowledge representation?

A. Makes relationships explicit
B. Works at the right level of abstraction
C. Is transparent and concise
D. Guarantees optimal solutions
E. Is computable

✓ A. Makes relationships explicit
✓ B. Works at the right level of abstraction
✓ C. Is transparent and concise
✗ D. Guarantees optimal solutions
✓ E. Is computable

Correct: A, B, C, E
Lesson 03 - Section 09
Which describe the generate-and-test method?

A. Generates candidate solutions
B. Tests solutions for acceptability
C. Requires complete world knowledge
D. Can use smart generators or testers
E. Always finds the optimal solution

✓ A. Generates candidate solutions
✓ B. Tests solutions for acceptability
✗ C. Requires complete world knowledge
✓ D. Can use smart generators or testers
✗ E. Always finds the optimal solution

Correct: A, B, D
Lesson 04
Which are steps in means-ends analysis?

A. Compare current and goal states
B. Identify differences
C. Select operators to reduce differences
D. Always return to the initial state
E. Apply operators iteratively

✓ A. Compare current and goal states
✓ B. Identify differences
✓ C. Select operators to reduce differences
✗ D. Always return to the initial state
✓ E. Apply operators iteratively

Correct: A, B, C, E
Lesson 05
Which are true of problem reduction?

A. Decomposes problems into subproblems
B. Solves subproblems independently
C. Guarantees optimality
D. Recombines sub-solutions
E. Applies only to planning

✓ A. Decomposes problems into subproblems
✓ B. Solves subproblems independently
✗ C. Guarantees optimality
✓ D. Recombines sub-solutions
✗ E. Applies only to planning

Correct: A, B, D
Lesson 05 - Section 18
Which are components of a production system?

A. Working memory
B. Long-term memory
C. Procedural knowledge
D. Episodic knowledge
E. Purely reactive rules

✓ A. Working memory
✓ B. Long-term memory
✓ C. Procedural knowledge
✗ D. Episodic knowledge
✗ E. Purely reactive rules

Correct: A, B, C
Lesson 06
Which are properties of frames?

A. Represent stereotypical knowledge
B. Support default values
C. Allow inheritance
D. Only encode numerical data
E. Handle exceptions

✓ A. Represent stereotypical knowledge
✓ B. Support default values
✓ C. Allow inheritance
✗ D. Only encode numerical data
✓ E. Handle exceptions

Correct: A, B, C, E
Lesson 07
Which are steps in learning by recording cases?

A. Store experiences as cases
B. Retrieve similar past cases
C. Always adapt the retrieved case
D. Apply prior solutions
E. Use only symbolic similarity

✓ A. Store experiences as cases
✓ B. Retrieve similar past cases
✗ C. Always adapt the retrieved case
✓ D. Apply prior solutions
✗ E. Use only symbolic similarity

Correct: A, B, D
Lesson 08
Which are phases of case-based reasoning?

A. Retrieval
B. Adaptation
C. Evaluation
D. Storage
E. Randomization

✓ A. Retrieval
✓ B. Adaptation
✓ C. Evaluation
✓ D. Storage
✗ E. Randomization

Correct: A, B, C, D
Lesson 09
Which are types of concepts in classification?

A. Axiomatic
B. Prototype
C. Exemplar
D. Random
E. Qualitative

✓ A. Axiomatic
✓ B. Prototype
✓ C. Exemplar
✗ D. Random
✗ E. Qualitative

Correct: A, B, C
Lesson 11
Which are logical connectives?

A. AND
B. OR
C. NOT
D. IMPLIES
E. EQUALS

✓ A. AND
✓ B. OR
✓ C. NOT
✓ D. IMPLIES
✗ E. EQUALS

Correct: A, B, C, D
Lesson 12
Which are rules of inference?

A. Modus Ponens
B. Modus Tollens
C. Resolution
D. Deduction
E. Induction

✓ A. Modus Ponens
✓ B. Modus Tollens
✓ C. Resolution
✗ D. Deduction
✗ E. Induction

Correct: A, B, C
Lesson 12
Which describe formal logic in AI?

A. Can be sound
B. Can be complete
C. Requires a correct knowledge base
D. Is always computationally efficient
E. Can support planning

✓ A. Can be sound
✓ B. Can be complete
✓ C. Requires a correct knowledge base
✗ D. Is always computationally efficient
✓ E. Can support planning

Correct: A, B, C, E
Lesson 12
Which are steps in resolution theorem proving?

A. Convert to conjunctive normal form
B. Negate the goal
C. Resolve clause pairs
D. Derive a contradiction
E. Use only Modus Ponens

✓ A. Convert to conjunctive normal form
✓ B. Negate the goal
✓ C. Resolve clause pairs
✓ D. Derive a contradiction
✗ E. Use only Modus Ponens

Correct: A, B, C, D
Lesson 12
An AI agent operates in a dynamic, partially observable world with limited computation. Which design choices most directly address multiple AI conundrums simultaneously?

A. Using heuristics instead of optimal search
B. Encoding global constraints explicitly in every state
C. Leveraging recurring problem patterns
D. Delaying action until all data is available
E. Integrating learning with reasoning

✓ A. Using heuristics instead of optimal search
✗ B. Encoding global constraints explicitly in every state
✓ C. Leveraging recurring problem patterns
✗ D. Delaying action until all data is available
✓ E. Integrating learning with reasoning

Correct: A, C, E
Lesson 01 - Applied
Which problem characteristics most strongly motivate the use of knowledge-based methods over purely statistical methods?

A. Problems recur with structural similarity
B. Solutions must be explainable
C. Data is abundant and labeled
D. Reasoning requires abstraction across levels
E. Problems are strictly numeric

✓ A. Problems recur with structural similarity
✓ B. Solutions must be explainable
✗ C. Data is abundant and labeled
✓ D. Reasoning requires abstraction across levels
✗ E. Problems are strictly numeric

Correct: A, B, D
Lesson 01 - Applied
An AI agent fails when encountering a novel situation despite extensive prior knowledge. Which limitations are most relevant?

A. Deductive reasoning bias
B. Incomplete world knowledge
C. Lack of inductive mechanisms
D. Excessive computational resources
E. Fixed representations

✓ A. Deductive reasoning bias
✓ B. Incomplete world knowledge
✓ C. Lack of inductive mechanisms
✗ D. Excessive computational resources
✓ E. Fixed representations

Correct: A, B, C, E
Lesson 01 - Applied
Why are reasoning, learning, and memory treated as a unified system in KBAI?

A. Learning creates knowledge used by reasoning
B. Reasoning generates new knowledge to store
C. Memory constrains what can be learned
D. Each process can operate independently without loss
E. Feedback loops improve adaptability

✓ A. Learning creates knowledge used by reasoning
✓ B. Reasoning generates new knowledge to store
✓ C. Memory constrains what can be learned
✗ D. Each process can operate independently without loss
✓ E. Feedback loops improve adaptability

Correct: A, B, C, E
Lesson 01 - Applied
An agent that plans routes optimally but ignores human conventions best fits which AI school(s)?

A. Thinking optimally
B. Acting optimally
C. Thinking like humans
D. Acting like humans
E. Cognitive systems

✓ A. Thinking optimally
✓ B. Acting optimally
✗ C. Thinking like humans
✗ D. Acting like humans
✗ E. Cognitive systems

Correct: A, B
Lesson 01 - Applied
Which learning strategies most directly support metacognition in CS7637?

A. Learning by reflection
B. Learning by example
C. Project-based learning
D. Personalized learning paths
E. Rote memorization

✓ A. Learning by reflection
✗ B. Learning by example
✓ C. Project-based learning
✗ D. Personalized learning paths
✗ E. Rote memorization

Correct: A, C
Lesson 02 - Applied
Which CS7637 principles explain why KBAI systems favor 'good-enough' solutions?

A. Bounded rationality
B. Incremental learning
C. Heuristic reasoning
D. Optimality guarantees
E. Trade-offs between efficiency and accuracy

✓ A. Bounded rationality
✗ B. Incremental learning
✓ C. Heuristic reasoning
✗ D. Optimality guarantees
✓ E. Trade-offs between efficiency and accuracy

Correct: A, C, E
Lesson 01 - Applied
A semantic network fails to solve a Raven's problem even though all objects are represented. What is the most likely cause?

A. Missing relational links
B. Excessive numeric detail
C. Inconsistent vocabulary
D. Incorrect node labels
E. Lack of procedural knowledge

✓ A. Missing relational links
✗ B. Excessive numeric detail
✗ C. Inconsistent vocabulary
✗ D. Incorrect node labels
✗ E. Lack of procedural knowledge

Correct: A
Lesson 03 - Applied
Which trade-offs define a poor knowledge representation?

A. Captures too much irrelevant detail
B. Omits necessary relationships
C. Uses abstraction strategically
D. Prevents inference
E. Is computationally expensive

✓ A. Captures too much irrelevant detail
✓ B. Omits necessary relationships
✗ C. Uses abstraction strategically
✓ D. Prevents inference
✓ E. Is computationally expensive

Correct: A, B, D, E
Lesson 03 - Applied
Generate-and-test becomes infeasible primarily due to:

A. Combinatorial explosion
B. Incomplete testers
C. Excessive abstraction
D. Redundant state generation
E. Overly expressive representations

✓ A. Combinatorial explosion
✗ B. Incomplete testers
✗ C. Excessive abstraction
✓ D. Redundant state generation
✗ E. Overly expressive representations

Correct: A, D
Lesson 04 - Applied
Means-ends analysis fails in some problems because:

A. Reducing one difference may increase another
B. Distance metrics may be misleading
C. Goals can interfere with each other
D. Operators are always reversible
E. It assumes monotonic progress

✓ A. Reducing one difference may increase another
✓ B. Distance metrics may be misleading
✓ C. Goals can interfere with each other
✗ D. Operators are always reversible
✓ E. It assumes monotonic progress

Correct: A, B, C, E
Lesson 05 - Applied
Problem reduction is most effective when:

A. Subproblems are independent
B. Subgoals can be ordered
C. Knowledge guides decomposition
D. All subproblems are equally difficult
E. Subsolutions compose cleanly

✓ A. Subproblems are independent
✓ B. Subgoals can be ordered
✓ C. Knowledge guides decomposition
✗ D. All subproblems are equally difficult
✓ E. Subsolutions compose cleanly

Correct: A, B, C, E
Lesson 05 - Applied
In production systems, impasses are important because they:

A. Trigger learning
B. Reveal missing knowledge
C. Indicate inconsistent rules
D. Halt reasoning permanently
E. Enable chunk formation

✓ A. Trigger learning
✓ B. Reveal missing knowledge
✗ C. Indicate inconsistent rules
✗ D. Halt reasoning permanently
✓ E. Enable chunk formation

Correct: A, B, E
Lesson 06 - Applied
Frames are preferred over flat representations when:

A. Defaults are common
B. Exceptions must be handled
C. Inheritance structures exist
D. Only numerical computation is needed
E. Knowledge is hierarchical

✓ A. Defaults are common
✓ B. Exceptions must be handled
✓ C. Inheritance structures exist
✗ D. Only numerical computation is needed
✓ E. Knowledge is hierarchical

Correct: A, B, C, E
Lesson 07 - Applied
Case-based reasoning outperforms rule-based reasoning when:

A. Problems are ill-structured
B. Exact rules are unavailable
C. Similar past experiences exist
D. Perfect generalization is required
E. Adaptation is possible

✓ A. Problems are ill-structured
✓ B. Exact rules are unavailable
✓ C. Similar past experiences exist
✗ D. Perfect generalization is required
✓ E. Adaptation is possible

Correct: A, B, C, E
Lesson 09 - Applied
Failure in case-based reasoning most often results from:

A. Poor similarity metrics
B. Over-generalized cases
C. Inadequate adaptation knowledge
D. Excessive storage capacity
E. Lack of retrieval constraints

✓ A. Poor similarity metrics
✓ B. Over-generalized cases
✓ C. Inadequate adaptation knowledge
✗ D. Excessive storage capacity
✓ E. Lack of retrieval constraints

Correct: A, B, C, E
Lesson 09 - Applied
Incremental concept learning heuristics are useful because they:

A. Allow gradual refinement
B. Avoid complete relearning
C. Support explanation
D. Guarantee correctness
E. Encode constraints explicitly

✓ A. Allow gradual refinement
✓ B. Avoid complete relearning
✓ C. Support explanation
✗ D. Guarantee correctness
✗ E. Encode constraints explicitly

Correct: A, B, C

✗ C. Axioms only
✓ D. Hybrid representations
✓ E. Feature-weighted concepts
